conclusion: Analyze how shadows A, B, C, and D change when the light source moves to the right, directly above the objects.
The image shows a table with various colored blocks and two fabric-like objects.
Assume the blocks labeled A, B, C, and D are elevated and casting shadows.
Assume the four objects are the blocks labeled A (yellow), B (purple), C (brown), D (blue).
Assume the initial light source position is to the left of the objects.
With the light source to the left, shadows are cast to the right of each object.
Shadows are slightly larger than the base of the blocks due to the light's angle.
Light source moves to the right, directly above the objects.
Light source directly above means light rays are perpendicular to the slab.
Shadows are cast directly beneath the objects with no lateral displacement.
Shadows A, B, C, and D will be directly beneath their respective blocks.
Shadows maintain relative arrangement but are directly under their respective blocks.
With light directly above, shadow size matches the base dimensions of the objects.
New shadows will be smaller in length compared to the initial elongated shadows.
Height of objects affects shadow sharpness but not location.
Point light source results in sharp shadows.
Blocks are cubic, so shadows will be square when light is directly above.
Initially, shadows were to the right of the objects due to the light source being on the left.
After movement, shadows are directly beneath their respective objects.
Initially, shadows were elongated due to angled light.
After movement, shadows match the size of the blocks' bases.
Final answer: Shadows move from being to the right of the objects to directly beneath them, with sizes decreasing to match the blocks' bases.
